content:
Alternate Steps 8 and 9:
(Alternate). Filter the plutei suspension through Nitex-Z8 um.
Save the filtrate that contains ectoderm cells. Collect the retentate which
contains the bags into MFSW. Sediment and wash the bag fraction until it is free of
contaminating ectoderm cells as described in Step 8 above. NOTE: This step
results in a purer bag fraction than Step 8 above that is easier to rid of
contaminating ectoderm cells, however, several bags are lost by sticking to the
Nitex.
(Alternate). Sediment the ectoderm cells out of the filtrate (which should be free
of bags) by centrifuging as described in Step 9 above and resuspend the cells in
MFSW.
Purification of Endoderm Cell Suspensions from Bag Fractions
NOTE: The details for this procedure have not yet been worked out for S.
purpuratus.
Briefly (try l-2 min and 3-li min to determine optimal time), incubate purified bags
on ice in glycine-EDTA.
Sediment the bags as in Step 8 above, resuspend in and triturate as in
Step 7. A
Filter the suspension through Nitex-28 um. The filtrate should contain a mixture of
mesoderm and remaining ectoderm cells. Discard.
Resuspend the retentate (intact endoderm) in glycine-EDTA and incubate aliquots
for 3, Ll, 8 minutes (to determine the optimal incubation time) on ice.
Sediment, resuspend in and triturate for a third time. Endoderm cells
should separate from each other and from the skeleton to give a suspension of
endoderm cells.
Test for Purity of Isolation
To assess the purity of the dissociations, the preparations may be examined for
alkaline phosphatase activity. Endoderm cells have high levels of alkaline phosphatase
activity, and in situ histochemical staining for enzymatic activity is selective for these
cells Intact embryos, bags, and purified ectoderm cells and endoderm cells should be
tested.
Place cells or embryos in a shallow depression slide in several drops of MFSW.
Add several drops of 0.2596 naphthol-AS-MX phosphate (PH 8.6) to the suspension.
Add l-2 grains of the diazonium salt, fast blue RR. Naphthol AS-MX formed at
sites of alkaline phosphatase activity produces an insoluble azo pigment. Optimum
alkaline phosphatase activity should be observed in about 5 min.
Based on the percent positive cells (frequency of dye deposits) observed
(microscopically) in each, determine the purity of the ectoderm and endoderm
preparations.
